lg.l: “I do not see him with the strength of a solitary wheel [= the sun]
Who ruled the entirety of the world, having spread his expanding rays.
Where is he, the prosperous one - the moon -, who spreads moonlight
Across the sky over there?” Saying [so],
[Her] face [made of the four] directions having faded,
As the red-lotus eyes overflow with whole [= full] tears,
The lady [who is] the vast earth [with] a dress of wavy waters [= the ocean],
In the time of unhappiness that came at night, the king having been brought to ruin,
While clans that had [=paid] tribute [to him] placed [their] hands [on their] heads [in shame],
Like a foreign king who sat [= occupied] to remain on [this] soil,
By way of the absence of the [true] king with a mighty army,
[The foreign king] having captured one part [of the land] with clans that are declining [in reputation],
As those who abandoned their desired/depressed companions reach [a state of] solitary misery,
As those who united with their lovers reached [a state of] intoxicating joy,
As prattling bees bloat, having placed their mouths on the Mullai flower that grows on [girls’] tresses
Along with herdsmen who blow in the Mullai melody, having placed their mouths on a flute [from which the melody grows],
The prosperous one - the small wind -
Having thrown off [=conquered] the stronghold of severing wind/the six-footed bee,
Spreading [throughout] the street of the prosperous one [Kōvalaṉ],
As women with bright bangles raise sapphire lamps,
Because the evening, having come, lingered in the ancient town of the prosperous one [= the Cōḻa king];
The crescent moon, even though he is young, having appeared in the sky,
Because the fightiang, famous clan of the southerners [Pāṇṭiyas]
That drive away enemy kings was [his] first/priority [= primary enemy],
Overthrowing the stronghold of the distressing evening, driving [it] off,
Spreading his milky rays that do not change in quality,
Under the silver lamp [= the moon] that was ruled by the king of stars [Kāmaṉ],
Flourishing inside the room with a many-flowered bed upon which Mallikai opened with home-grown Mullai,
[Her] girdle [upon] the pretty, fine cloth - being one that is displaced - suffering,
[At her] eminent hip around which a red-coral string had gone,
Upon the terrace with the long moonlight where [one] takes the benefits of the moonlight,
Being joyful [with] the lover through union and through sulking [= amorous tiffs],
Apart from Mātavi who took appearance opposite to Kōvalaṉ with a keen heart,
Abandoning [= putting out] the dark eagle-wood [incense] from the easterly direction
Along with the white powder [incense] from the westerly direction,
Grinding sandal that was born in the southern mountains
On a pure, lustrous circle [= grindstone] born in the northern mountains,
Mingling a garland of lotus, rich shoots,
Ample blossoms from which pollen falls, desirous waterlily,
Lotus and big blossoms, and a string of big pearls
Strewing [that mixture] upon the flourishing flower-bed of affection,
[The lovers] rejoicing as they who were confused [in love]
Hiding among the chests of yawning husbands,
[The girls] reaching [a state of] intoxicated sleep with [their] lotus-like, pretty eyes;
As the beautiful anklets on the pretty, red, small feet are forsaken,
The girdle on the hip with tender, fine cloth falling off,
She [Kaṇṇaki] did not draw upon the front of her breasts with vermillion.
Apart from the auspicious ornament [marriage cord], she did not rejoice in adornments.
Abandoning curved earrings, she was of drooping ears, having diminished.
As small [beads of] perspiration separated from [her] moon-like, bright face,
As her red, carp-like, long eyes forget kajal,
As the coral-like, bright forehead forgets the Tilakam mark,
As Kōvalaṉ [thus] lost [the sight of her] white, bright smile,
As the dark tresses forget the adornment of oil,
Apart from Kaṇṇaki with a helpless heart,
As ladies who had been separated from their lovers experienced pain,
Being restrained as those who sigh like the wader bird[-shaped] fire-bellows (?),
Not desiring the summer resting-place, going past [it],
Blocking the short eye[-like windows] of the resting place of the cold season,
Suffering, their bosoms not having enjoyed [the adornment of]
The substance from the Mayala region [= sandal], [nor] a garland of sapphires and pearls,
Passing up, not desiring a bed upon which flowers [such as]
The cool, red lotus along with waterlily [grown in a] pot had fallen,
Lying upon a bed [made for] a pair, which was dense with
Feathers from a goose that had united with its companion,
Amidst the time of quarelling with their great husbands with whom they were,
Throwing [up] the middle-cone/bulb [= flaring their nostrils],
Driving the ends [of their eyes] to [as far as their] earrings,
The ends [of their eyes] becoming red [with anger],
As their long eyes that were stretched out sideways
[With] the tender gait of a goose,
[Like] hoards of honey that are fragrant in the pond-waterlily,
As bees with the mouth of a bard sing the Nōtiṟam melody (?),
As [the ladies] open the flowers [which are their] eyes,
As the conch that is the thorny mouth of a rooster with spotted feathers
Roars again and again along with the drum that is the bird’s mouth,
Arousing the sleep of the town like an expanse of vigorous waters,
At the limit of dawn that moves away the night, at half-darkness,
As he who did not sleep [at] midnight [nor] midday,
The young man [with] a victorious banner [with] a crocodile [sigil] roams about,
[His] watch over the city was very superior.
